Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ligule development in the proximal-distal axis of the maize leaf
Award.AbstractNarration:
Alteration in plant architecture has been critically important during crop domestication. Through generations of breeding to increase yield, crop plants have been selected for a variety of branching patterns that change the number, length or angle of branches. In maize, leaf angle has been an important branching trait that has likely contributed to increasing corn yields. The angle of the leaf is determined by the ligule region, which forms at the boundary between the blade and sheath. The blade tilts back to absorb energy from the sun while the sheath holds tight to the stem. This angle between the blade and sheath is a heritable trait that can be modified through selection: decreased angle makes plants more upright for more compact fields, whereas increased angle optimizes the surface area of the blade for more energy capture. Thus, understanding the basic molecular mechanisms involved in establishing the leaf angle will provide new tools for manipulating maize architecture. This project aims to clarify the complex network of factors that determine when and how the ligule region forms. This project will first identify and characterize the expression of genes that define the ligule boundary during the earliest stages of development. Molecular, genetic and genomic methods will then be used to investigate how the ligule region forms. The results will be shared with diverse audiences including breeders, the scientific community and with students. To that end, YouTube videos will be produced that describe the science of corn development to a general audience and additional educational materials will be generated for student classrooms. All resources will be made publically available through lab websites and the maize community website (http://www.maizegdb.org).

This project investigates how the ligular region is established as a defined organ boundary in the undifferentiated leaf primordium. Previous work used the anatomically distinct ligule as a site for transcriptome analysis: preligule, preblade and presheath cells were clearly identified for laser capture followed by RNA sequencing. Due to the specificity of capture, a collection of candidate genes was identified that is uniquely and differentially expressed in the ligule region. Shared expression patterns in other organ boundaries suggest that the ligule reiterates the lateral organ initiation program that occurs at the shoot apical meristem and at tassel branch boundaries. Thus, distinctly different organ boundaries are hypothesized to share genes and use common mechanisms to define and restrict developmental pathways. To test this hypothesis, gene networks will be established for early stages of ligule development and mechanisms of ligule initiation further investigated. The first specific aim is to identify the earliest determinants of ligule formation by capturing cells from the youngest accessible leaf primordia. Candidate genes will be prioritized based on their expression in other ligule-specific mutants. The second aim investigates three promising candidate gene pathways that support the role of KNOTTED1 (KN1)-like homeobox transcription factors and partner proteins in establishing the ligule boundary. Mutants will be analyzed in these genes for ligule and branching phenotypes. The third aim tests the hypothesis that the bZIP transcription factor LIGULELESS2 (LG2), bound by KN1, is involved in positioning the blade/sheath boundary. Protein partners will be identified as will down-stream targets to determine the role of LG2 in establishing the blade sheath boundary.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background and Intellectual Merit. Maize has been selected through domestication to have exceptionally large leaves with blades that display maximum surface area for photosynthesis. The flat blade projects out at an angle from the plant and connects through a ligular region to a lower sheath, which wraps around the stem and provides support. It is well-known that genetic variation in the growth and placement of the ligular region alters the angle of the blade, thus impacting the plant's architecture. Blade angle is one of the features that contributes to making corn a highly yielding and critically important crop that provides feed, fuel and fodder world-wide. A major goal for the future is to continue providing for the expanding population, while designing corn plants to conserve precious space and resources. Smaller, tighter plants that need less water and space would go a long way towards achieving this goal. For this reason, understanding how the leaf grows, when the boundary between blade and sheath forms, and how the ligular region is established will provide the tools and resources to vary plant architecture to grow efficiently in new environments.

Methods, Results, and Outcomes. The collaborative team on this project studied when and how the ligular region is first established during maize leaf development. Prior genetic studies had pointed to proteins that regulate when the leaf is first initiated, and early studies showed how the ligule itself emerges from a structure called a preligule band. However, by the time the preligule band forms, the basic blueprint of blade and sheath is likely already established. This project tested this hypothesis using genomic tools to identify all the genes that are uniquely or differentially expressed in small regions of one of the youngest developing leaves (called the P4 primordium). A laser was used to capture specific cell types in this young leaf in which blade and sheath had not yet differentiated. After sequencing all the RNA that had been captured, the team used machine learning to analyze the data along with visualization methods to show where specific genes were expressed. The results identified a pre-pattern of gene expression that predicts the future blade and sheath boundary within a network of regulatory genes at the earliest stages of growth. Candidate genes were tested and were analyzed by ChIP-Seq (chromatin immunoprecipitation with massively parallel DNA sequencing) and CoIP (chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by mass-spectrometry analysis), which are both methods that allow for identifying targets and other interacting proteins. Together these results demonstrated how positional information is distributed at the base of an early primordium, helping to establish the future blade sheath boundary long before any morphological evidence of ligular outgrowth. These findings, and a wealth of candidate genes, help explain how the boundary is established, point to genes that could be critical to modifying blade and sheath for better efficiency of growth, and provide access to a rich resource of gene candidates for future study.

Broader Impacts. This collaborative team has significantly contributed to an inclusive training and education environment in science and plant biology. Seven post-doctoral researches were trained and contributed to the research in this project. All have continued in a diversity of scientific careers including in academia as assistant professors, industry, science editorial, or patent law. Four graduate students were trained, along with three undergraduate students, including two from groups traditionally under-represented in science. Visits to middle schools in rural communities focused on age-appropriate discussion of corn growth. A "How To" video was produced to share methods for dissecting and conducting research on corn. In addition to these educational efforts, results from this research are publicly released to public repositories and so are freely accessible and useable by the research community.
